answers.author: Michael Silvestri
answers.text:
We have a public safety director that is also the Police Chief.  Frankly, the responsibilities of a fire chief were too technical and time consuming for the Police Chief to serve in both functions.  In addition, the firefighters both paid an volunteers respond to someone who is a fully functioning and certified firefighter.  This position may be possible in a larger environment, but does not work in a smaller community.

answers.author: Ralph McLaughlin
answers.text:
I agree with a Public Safety Manager (PSM) concept whereby the Police and Fire Chief report to a PSM as opposed to an assistant, deputy or City/County manager. This PSM will/should have experience in both disciplines, Police and Fire.
I see a problem with eliminating Chiefs of these very different disciplines. While both are focused on public safety, each have very differing tactics, job requirements, employee base, customer base etc. etc. Having the staff of Fire and Police report to ‘One Master’ might pose problems down the road. I can go on and on with this topic. Feel free to contact me at rmclaughlin@goodyearaz.gov.

answers.author: Gary West
answers.text:
You may wish to look at the experience of Edina, Minnesota (Warren Hyde (deceased), City Manager) during the late 1970s. The transition to a single Public Safety Director took place with the retirements of a long-time Police Chief and Fire Chief, I believe in 1975. The Assistant Fire Chief, a 15+ year employee who was a skilled administrator and top flight fire safety technician (adjunct professor at Tulane, in fire safety) was chosen to lead the two organizations.
The two departments had a long history of cooperation and cross-training of the police officers in fire supression. In addition, as a result of financial incentives, a majority of the two departments had at least an AA degree, or a BA. So, the officers and fire fighters were generally more intellectually open to change.
I believe the experiment lasted into the 1980s. I had moved on by then and lost track.
I agree with Ralph that there are difficulties with making it work, not the least of which in Edina was the disparate union contracts (police - Teamsters, fire fighters - IAFF). The key is the skill of the Chief in forging a cooperative effort and achieving credibility with the rank and file.

answers.author: Thomas Wieczorek
answers.text:
Having been a public safety director and overseen the consolidation of a police and fire department into a fully cross-trained department, the key to a consolidation is recognition by political, community, and employees. Too often one group or the other will "wait and hope" things will revert or (overtly and covertly) encourage such a change; only when it is embraced and recognized as the method for delivering services will it be successful. One can look at several cities in Michigan: Ionia, Petoskey, Greenville, Berkley or Southlake, Texas. All are smaller communities with different populations and demands. All made the transition and continue to deliver higher quality services than prior to the consolidation. 
A public safety director will need a good "number 2" in police and fire for the director will be concentrating on administration, planning, and organizational functions. The number 2 person works with the groups and, if not fully consolidated, must deal with the differences. Police normally operate as individuals and are fairly independent; fire function and train as teams. I found the fire background persons ideal for public education (including D.A.R.E. and school liaisons) because it exploited those differences.

author: Pamela Muse
text:
An Alliance member is reviewing the option of consolidating the Police and Fire Chief’s position to a single Chief overseeing both police and fire.  Not consolidating the departments, just the two Chief’s into one.
Very interested in hearing from those agencies that have consolidated at the Chief level, or know of other agencies that have.  Pros/Cons, opinions, data, etc. Welcome!
Pamela Muse
Western Regional Director
Alliance for Innovation
888-468-6450
pmuse@transformgov.org
title: Combining Chief of Police & Fire Chief Into One Position
